description: From Medieval Latin heterogeneus, from Ancient Greek ἑτερογενής (heterogenḗs, “of different kinds”), from ἕτερος (héteros, “other, another, different”) + γένος (génos, “kind”). Compare hetero- and -ous.

adjectives.description: heterogeneous (comparative more heterogeneous, superlative most heterogeneous)

entries.meaning: Diverse in kind or nature; composed of diverse parts.
examples: He had a large and heterogeneous collection of books.

entries.meaning: (physics, chemistry) Having more than one phase (solid, liquid, gas) present in a system or process.

(computing) Of a network comprising different types of computers, potentially with vastly differing memory sizes, processing power and even basic underlying architecture; alternatively, of a data resource with multiple types of formats.
